evaluation.response:
Absolutely—happy to help. If you can, attach a photo of the worksheet or paste the problems Ms. K circled along with your answers and any work you showed. I’ll check them and point out exactly where the simplification is going wrong.

While you send that, here’s a quick fraction-simplifying checklist you can use:

- Reduce by the greatest common factor (GCF).
  - Try dividing by 2, 3, 5, etc., or use the Euclidean trick: GCF(48,60) = GCF(48, 60−48=12) = GCF(48,12) = 12.
- Only cancel factors, not terms.
  - Can cancel in 18/24 → (6·3)/(6·4) → 3/4.
  - Cannot cancel in (6+2)/2; do the addition first: 8/2 = 4.
- Keep negatives tidy: put the minus in front. −6/8 = −3/4, −6/−8 = 3/4.
- Multiplying fractions: multiply tops and bottoms, but cross-cancel first if possible.
  - Example: (14/15)·(25/21) → cross-cancel 7 and 21, 5 and 25 → (2/3)·(5/3) = 10/9.
- Dividing fractions: multiply by the reciprocal, then reduce.
  - Example: (8/12) ÷ (4/9) = (8/12)·(9/4) → cancel → (2/3)·(9/4) = 18/12 = 3/2.
- Adding/subtracting: get a common denominator first, combine numerators, then reduce.
  - Example: 5/12 + 7/18 → common denom 36 → 15/36 + 14/36 = 29/36.
- Mixed numbers: convert to improper for operations, then reduce and convert back if needed.
  - Example: 2 1/4 = 9/4.
- Special cases: 0/n = 0; n/0 is undefined; 1 is the “stop” sign—if GCF is 1, you’re done.

Common mistakes Ms. K might be circling:
- Canceling across a plus/minus: (a+b)/b ≠ a/b + 1; you can’t cancel the b.
- Stopping too early: 18/24 → 9/12 → 3/4 (go all the way to simplest form).
- Forgetting to reduce after adding/subtracting or after multiplying/dividing.

Send 3–5 of the circled problems with your answers, and I’ll walk through each step and fix them with you.

What the dots mean
- Green dot = camera is in use by an app.
- Orange dot = microphone is in use (dictation, Siri, video chat, etc.).
- They can flash briefly if an app checks the camera/mic for a moment (QR/code scanner, Notes’ document scanner, Meet/Zoom opening, a website you visited with camera permission, etc.).

About school iPads
- Teachers using Apple Classroom can see your screen and lock/open apps, but they cannot silently turn on your camera or mic.

Quick checks you can do
1) Catch the culprit: next time it appears, swipe down from the top-right to open Control Center. It will show a tiny camera/mic icon with the name of the app that just used it.
2) Review permissions: Settings > Privacy & Security > Camera (and Microphone). Turn off access for any app that doesn’t truly need it. For Safari: Settings > Safari > Camera/Microphone > set to Ask (or Deny).
3) Close and restart: swipe up to view open apps and flick away video/meeting/scanner apps; then restart the iPad. Update iPadOS if there’s an update (Settings > General > Software Update).

- Do a quick 4-in/6-out breathing set to calm the “someone’s watching me” surge.
